item.description:
Join us for a day of hiking. Lastest trip reports indicate that there is still snow in the mountains, so we are hoping to get some sledding done.

PRIOR EXPERIENCE HIKING TO PEAKS ABOVE 4,000 FEET IN WINTER CONDITIONS IS REQUIRED TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS EVENT.

Located along the Kinsman Ridge, South (4358’) is the highest point while North (4293’) is the second highest. Ledges just below the wooded summits offer great views of Lafayette and Lincoln across Franconia Notch.

While we will use our feet to get to the top of these two 4,000 foot peaks, we will come down using our sleds. You will need to bring your own small sled so you can join in the fun.

 

 

Click this link for the current weather forecast

 

 

We will meet at 8:00 AM Mount Kinsman Trailhead. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is about 146 miles away from Boston and it should take about 2 hours 36 minutes to drive there.

Click this link for driving directions

 

 

This moderate pace hike will cover about 10 miles and climb about 3,900 feet – it is considered Level 4 Intermediate/Advanced because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. It should take an average hiker about 8 hours 15 minutes to complete this trip in the summer, however, when you consider winter conditions and factor in rest breaks and sightseeing I expect us to be out for about 10 hours.

 

 

We start as a group, stay as a group, and finish as a group. If you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us or want to head off on your own, this isn't the trip for you. Likewise, this trip isn't for you if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you or want us to go on without you. If you have ANY questions about your ability to participate in and complete this entire event please contact me.

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. Winter hiking is more strenuous than hiking in the summer. We will assess travel and weather conditions and make changes to our planned trip as necessary - "Reaching the summit is optional, getting down in mandatory" (Ed Viesturs).

Below is a list describing the minimum clothing and equipment required to participate in this event.

 


  • Footwear: Waterproof/insulated winter hiking boots. Snow shoes and traction devices (e.g. Crampons or MICROspikes). Waterproof gaiters.
  • Clothing: Dress in layers to easily regulate body temperature. Wear synthetic shirt/pants and a fleece jacket/wool sweater - ABSOLUTELY NO COTTON. Ski goggles or sunglasses.
  • Outerwear: Waterproof/windproof rain jacket (with hood) and pants made of either coated nylon or breathable fabric (e.g. Gore-Tex or similar). Fleece hat, fleece balaclava or face shield, waterproof gloves, and waterproof over-mittens.
  • Food and Water: High-energy snacks, food for lunch/dinner, and at least three quarts of water.
  • Other Essential Gear: Map and compass, a plastic whistle, a headlamp with two sets of spare batteries, an emergency (e.g. mylar) space blanket, a small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool, trekking poles, a toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items), sunscreen, lip balm, and a waterproof cover for your pack.

 

You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

I will bring a group first aid kit that contains basic items but you will need to bring any medications or medical supplies that you may need during the trip.

 

 

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: We'll be driving a green Toyota Highlander
item.name: North and South Kinsman
